newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Fall in EU oilseeds seen reflecting shift to wheat.
newsitem.headline: Fall in EU oilseeds seen reflecting shift to wheat.

text.p: European Union oilseed producers have been turning to wheat production to secure higher prices and compensation payments, an EU official said on Tuesday.
The 1992 reform of the Common Agricultural Policy came into full effect in 1995/96 and offered arable farmers a higher return for wheat than oilseeds.

"Farmers saw record prices for wheat last year, and in addition increased compensation payments meant they would get a better return for increasing their area of wheat than for growing oilseeds," the official said.
"The return on oilseeds does not fluctuate but for wheat it does, with the security of compensation if it falls," the official added.
Oilseed production was estimated to have fallen to 12.26 million tonnes from 12.61 million in 1995 by COCERAL, the EU cereal trade umbrella group, on Tuesday.
The reduction was most marked in rapeseed, where the area planted fell from 2.88 million hectares to 2.64 million in 1996.
The overall oilseed area declined from 5.66 million hectares to 5.34 million.
The largest reductions in rapeseed area were in Sweden, Denmark, Germany and Britain.
The area planted to the crop rose marginally in France.
